awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:Does Restorative Justice Contribute to Human Rights and Peace? Explaining Diffusion and Evaluating Impacts Using a Multi-Method, Multi-Level Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Increasingly, states are choosing restorative justice mechanisms such as truth commissions and reparations to address past human rights harms. Transitional states now see transitional justice as a route to legitimacy and stability. Restorative justice advocates claim that truth commissions and reparations play a critical causal role in bringing about a diverse set of positive societal outcomes including improving human rights, democratic development, and consolidating peace. Despite the global diffusion of the restorative justice discourse and the widespread adoption of domestic truth commissions and reparations policies, there is little evidence that restorative justice actually works.  The first research question this project will address is: do restorative justice mechanisms contribute to improvements in human rights, democratic development, and peace consolidation, and if so, how? Second, if restorative justice does not have these positive impacts, then why have restorative justice policies diffused so widely and why do state officials, advocates, and academics continue to make claims about policy efficacy?  Applying a multi-method, multi-level approach to explain restorative justice diffusion and evaluate its impacts at the global and subnational levels, the research will clarify explanations for policy diffusion, and establish the relationship between different forms of justice (e.g. retributive, restorative) and reconciliation.  It will provide a much-needed evidence base to help guide policy design and help channel resources into the most impactful transitional justice and peacebuilding programs; and it will contribute to current policy debates about how to achieve sustainable peace.  

To empirically test different explanations for policy diffusion, the principal investigators (PIs) statistically analyze cross-national data from the NSF-supported Transitional Justice Research Collaborative (TJRC) database. They also utilize newly collected meso- and micro-level data from recent field work in Colombia to identify new diffusion pathways and construct different measures of (non-geographic) spatial nearness.  To evaluate the impact of restorative justice on human rights, democracy, and peace outcomes, the PIs statistically analyze cross-national data from the TJRC database and micro-level data from a recently completed Harvard-led population-based survey in Colombia. Supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant, the PIs will implement an innovative survey experiment in Colombia to explore the relationship between restorative justice and reconciliation -- the most commonly claimed outcome among restorative justice supporters. Utilizing an experimental vignette methodology (EVM), which uses survey sampling methods to produce a collection of experimental subjects and experimental methods to randomly assign participants to variations of the independent variable, they will test how different provisions of justice (e.g. restorative, retributive, distributive, and procedural) impact individual judgments about reconciliation. In transitional settings, these provisions of justice are delivered through transitional justice processes such as criminal prosecutions, truth commissions, and reparations. The experimental field survey helps establish and clarify pathways between different forms of justice and reconciliation, and will be used to explore how different forms and combinations of justice change subjective judgments about reconciliation. The research design draws from a basic comparative design according to which randomly selected individuals from different groups are compared. The PIs will make comparisons, among others, between the general population, war victims, and Afro-Colombians. The PIs draw on insights from political science, sociology, and anthropology in order to study restorative justice dynamics at the global and subnational levels.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the NSF-supported project are to develop and implement an experimental field survey to measures citizens? perceptions of retributive and restorative justice for past human rights abuse in Colombia. The survey utilizes an experimental vignette methodology to evaluate how different forms of retributive and restorative justice, such as criminal punishment, truth, material reparations and symbolic reparations, change respondents? beliefs about peace and reconciliation.

The experiment involves a prompt, treatments and outcomes. The prompt is an animated vignette which tells the story of a mid-level commander associated with one of four conflict actors: the FARC (insurgents), ELN (insurgents), AUC (paramilitary) or the Colombian Public Forces. The membership of the perpetrator is determined by a ?least-liked? technology where the respondent identifies the conflict actor ?most difficult to forgive.? The mid-level commander confesses before the Special Tribunal for Peace that he was involved in a massacre against civilians. After the prompt, respondents are randomly assigned one of five justice treatments. There are two retributive treatments, two restorative treatments, and a control treatment. The control and treatments were developed using the transitional justice framework developed during peace negotiations between the Government of Colombia and the FARC.

A general finding of the study is that reconciliation can be systematically and accurately measured using perceptual-level data. By measuring the concept at the appropriate level of analysis and using perceptual data, powerful effects are made visible. These effects are often not visible at the country-level, where many researchers search for them.

Another general finding is that for criminal punishment and truth, the micro-level findings complement the macro-level findings produced in various statistical studies which examine the effects of prosecutions and truth commissions on human rights and peace. Many of the cross-national studies find that criminal prosecutions positively impact state-level human rights and peace and truth commissions have a weakly positive or no impact. The micro-level results from this study support and enhance these findings. This study examines the impacts of prosecutions with criminal punishment, prosecutions with non-criminal punishment (e.g. community labor); monetary reparations, symbolic reparations, and truth on citizens? perceptions of peace and reconciliation.

The results also show that much of the conventional wisdom about how to achieve reconciliation in post-conflict contexts is incomplete and often incorrect. The conventional wisdom, supported by many academics and policy makers, is that restorative justice is the most effective way to achieve peace and reconciliation in transitional societies. In this context, restorative justice refers to the transitional justice mechanisms truth commissions and reparations. However, the results of the study show that the most effective way to change citizens? beliefs about peace and reconciliation is to punish perpetrators for serious human rights violations. The results also suggest that in most circumstances, non-criminal punishment (e.g. judicial sentences of community labor or restricted liberty) and criminal punishment (e.g. judicial sentences of incarceration) produce similar positive effects on beliefs about peace and reconciliation. There is little evidence to support the widespread belief that restorative justice has a large, significant and positive effect on beliefs about peace and reconciliation. Material reparations have a weakly positive effect on a few components of reconciliation (e.g. forgiveness and state-society repair through rights protection) but no observable effect on most. Symbolic reparations and truth worsen or have no effect on beliefs about peace or reconciliation. 

The findings suggest that retributive justice is necessary to bring about peace and reconciliation. For many outcomes, non-criminal punishment and criminal punishment have statistically indistinguishable effects. There is strong evidence challenging the claims that peace and (retributive) justice are incompatible and that (retributive) justice impedes reconciliation. Importantly, there is no evidence from this experiment that criminal punishment worsens beliefs about peace or reconciliation. In almost all circumstances, respondents who received the criminal punishment treatment have improved beliefs about reconciliation. The findings affirm that a just peace and complete ethic of reconciliation must include retributive justice.

Another important finding is that the three restorative justice mechanisms tested - truth, material reparations and symbolic reparations - have different effects on reconciliation. Truth and symbolic reparations worsen or have no effect on beliefs about reconciliation. For most reconciliation outcomes, material reparations weakly improve or have no effect on beliefs about reconciliation. Only when reconciliation is conceptualized as "forgiveness" or "state-society repair through rights protection," do material reparations have a strong, positive effect. None of the restorative justice mechanisms have an observable effect on beliefs in peace.

Finally, criminal punishment has a large, significant, positive effect on respondents beliefs about justice. Respondents who receive the criminal punishment treatment are seven times more likely to have positive beliefs about justice than the control group (truth). While this is not one of the main dependent variables in the study, beliefs about justice are central to the transitional justice project.
